text:
CURRENT AND ELECTRICITY

Electromagnetic induction is the production of electric current or voltage in a conductor whenever their is a relative motion between the conductor and magnetic field.

The two laws of electromagnetic induction are Faraday’s law and Lenz’s law.

Faraday’s law states that whenever there is a change in the magnetic line of force is induced, the strength of which is proportional to the rate of change of the flux linked with the circuit. 

Lenz’s law states that the induced e.m.f is in the direction as to oppose the motion producing it.

The principle of operation of the induction coil was given in 1831 by Michael Faraday. 

Ampere’s law states that two parallel wires attract each other when the current in them flow in the same direction, but repel each other when the currents in them flow in the same direction, but repel each other when the currents in them flow in opposite direction. 

Energy loss in the form of heating effect of the cable can be reduced by making the electricity generated in power stations to be of very high voltage for transmission. A high transmission voltage means only a relatively small current flows through the transmission cables. 

The primary aim in high tension transmission is to minimize electrical energy loses due to heat production. This is achieved by transmitting electricity under high voltage and lower current.

Eddy current is an induced current that damps and generate heat in material leading to energy wastage in most electrical devices. It is only desirable in moving coil instrument and follows Lenz’s law in direction.

Example

Energy losses through eddy currents are reduced by using

A. low resistance wires. B. high resistance wires.

C. few turns of wire. D. insulated soft iron wires.

D. Energy losses through eddy currents are reduced by using insulated soft iron wires.

 

Example

From the generating station to each substation, power is transmitted at a very high voltage so as to reduce

A. hystersis loss, B. eddy current loss, C. magnetic flux leakage, D. heating in the coils.

 D. (2005/2006, no 8).

to reduce heating in the coils.

 

Example

The primary aim in high tension transmission is to

A. Minimize electrical energy loses due to heat production. B. Increase the rate of energy transfers by using high voltage

C. Increase the current-in the wires, D. Generate electricity at high current and low voltage

A (2007/2008, no 12)

 

Calculating Internal and external Resistance

I = 

E = I(R + r)

V = E – Ir

Where E = e.m.f, V = terminal p.d., I = current, R = external resistance, r = internal resistance.

Terminal p.d is always less than the E, e.m.f of the cell by the lost voltage v.

V = E – v

 

Example

A 12V battery has an internal resistance of 0.5Ω. If a cable of 1.0Ω resistance is connected across the terminals of the battery, the current drawn from die battery is

A. 16.0A, B. 8.0A, C. 0.4A, D. 0.4 A

B (2005/2006, no6)

E = I(R + r)

E = 12, R = 0.5, r = 1.0

12 = I(0.5 + 1.0) = 1.5  I

I =  = 8

I = 8A

 

Step-up Transformer 

This is a type of transformer that increases the voltage applied or primary voltage, it has more of secondary turns. ES > EP. NS > NP. 

Step-down Transformer

This is a type of transformer that decreases or steps down the primary voltage. It has more of primary turns. ES < EP. NS < NP.

Generally,

 = 

Current is inversely proportional to the number of turns but the voltage are directly proportional to the number of turns.

Example 

A transformer has a primary coil with 500 turns and a secondary coil with 2500 turns and a secondary coil with 2500 turns. When the voltage input to the primary is 120V, the output is ____.

A. 6000 V, B. 600 V, C. 240 V, D. 60 V

B (2995/2006, no 11)

 = 

500/2500 = 120/ES 

ES = (120  2500)/500 = 600V

 

 

 

 

 

MACHINE

A machine is a device or tool which allows a force (effort) applied at one point to overcome a resisting force (or load0 at another point. 

Mechanical advantage is the ability of a machine to overcome a large load through a small effort.

Mechanical advantage = 

Mechanical advantage = 

Velocity ratio is the ratio of distance moved by effort and the load, in the same time interval.

Velocity ratio = 

Mechanical efficiency is basically a measure of what you get out (useful output) of what you put in (inputs in the form of energy). The formular is given by

Efficiency = 

Efficiency = 

The efficiency of a machine is always less than 100% because the velocity ratio is always greater than the mechanical advantage.

Example

A machine whose efficiency is 60% has a velocity ratio of 5. If a force of 500N is applied to lift a load of P(N), what is the magnitude of P?

A. 750N, B. 4166N, C. 500N, D. 1500N

D (2009/2010, no 4)

A body of weight W Newton rests on a smooth plane inclined at an angle 0° to the horizontal will have a normal reaction to the plane on the body which is given by

Vertical and Horizontal Component 

The horizontal component is given by W  (horizontal component)

the component of the weight down the slope is given by

You can just notice that horizontal component always goes with cos, while vertical component always goes with sin.
